Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of a building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs to reach his apartment on the 10th floor.
However, on rainy days and when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

Why does he normally get off on the 7th floor? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why the man gets off the elevator on the 7th floor normally.
Let me try to break this down step by step.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor.
That makes sense because it's efficient—no need to climb stairs when you're going down.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs to his apartment on the 10th floor.
Hmm, why not just go all the way up to the 10th floor? Maybe there's a reason related to the elevator's behavior.
On rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So, normally, he doesn't do that.
Why is that? Let me think about elevators.
If the elevator is full or if it's raining, maybe the elevator doesn't stop at certain floors.
Or perhaps the man avoids taking the elevator during those times because it's more crowded or uncomfortable.
Wait, maybe it's about the elevator's speed or efficiency.
If the elevator is going quickly, maybe he doesn't want to wait for it to stop at every floor.
But he still gets off at the 7th floor normally, so maybe the elevator isn't going all the way up every time.
Or perhaps the elevator only stops at certain floors during certain times.
Another angle: maybe the man is trying to save time or avoid waiting.
If he takes the elevator to the 7th floor, he can walk up the stairs quickly, especially if the stairs aren't too long.
But if the elevator is full or it's raining, he takes it all the way because it's faster or more convenient.
Wait, but the problem says that on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So normally, he doesn't do that.
So why does he normally get off at the 7th floor? Maybe because the elevator isn't full, or it's not raining, so he can control the elevator's stop.
But that doesn't explain why he stops at 7th floor.
Oh, perhaps the elevator only stops at certain floors, like every 5 floors, so it goes from ground to 5th, then 10th, etc.
So if he presses 7th, the elevator might not stop there unless he specifies it.
But that doesn't make sense because he can choose the floor he wants.
Wait, maybe the building's elevator has certain rules.
For example, maybe the elevator only stops at even floors or certain intervals.
If he presses 7th floor, the elevator might not stop there.
But the problem says he gets off on the 7th floor, so it does stop there normally.
Alternatively, maybe the man uses a specific elevator that stops at the 7th floor.
But that doesn't explain the difference between rainy days and normal days.
Another thought: maybe the man works on the ground floor, so he goes down in the morning and comes back up.
But when he comes back, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up because maybe the stairs are closer or it's faster than waiting for the elevator to go all the way up.

Maybe that's quicker than waiting for the elevator to go all the way up, especially if the elevator is slow or if it's not convenient.
But why does he do that only in the evening and not in the morning? In the morning, he goes all the way down, but in the evening, he stops at 7th.
Maybe because in the evening, he's less in a hurry or the elevator is less crowded.
Wait, but the key point is that on rainy days and when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So normally, he doesn't do that.

So why does he normally get off at the 7th floor? Maybe because on normal days, the elevator isn't full, so he can control where it stops, but when it's full or raining, the elevator goes all the way up.
Wait, perhaps the elevator's behavior changes based on the number of people in it.
If there are other people, it goes to the top floor, so he gets off at 7th because he wants to avoid waiting or because the elevator doesn't stop there when it's full.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator only stops at the 7th floor when it's not full.
So on normal days, it stops at 7th, but when it's full, it goes all the way to 10th.
But I'm not entirely sure.
Maybe I should think about the elevator's programming.
If the elevator is programmed to go to the top floor when it's full or when it's raining, then on normal days, it stops at 7th because it's not full and he can get off there.

So the man prefers to get off at 7th floor normally because the elevator isn't full, making it convenient for him to stop there, whereas on rainy days or when it's full, the elevator goes all the way up.

So the reason he normally gets off at the 7th floor is because the elevator isn't full, so he can control where it stops, whereas on rainy days or when it's full, the elevator goes directly to the 10th floor without stopping at 7th.

</think>

The man normally gets off the elevator on the 7th floor because, on regular days, the elevator isn't full, allowing him to stop there.
However, on rainy days or when the elevator is crowded, it goes directly to the 10th floor.
